intro: Erythracanthus pilosus, commonly known as the hairy erythracanthus, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Fabaceae, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its distinctive, hairy foliage. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that are clustered in racemes, often appearing in late winter to early spring. Its leaves are trifoliate, with each leaflet being hairy and oval-shaped. Erythracanthus pilosus is typically found in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid environments.
